stages.golden-age:
The story of Sosruquo survives in the Sagas of the Narts, repeating across languages and generations in the Caucasus. These stories preserve a memory from the hinge between the Bronze and Iron Ages, when the heroic imagination was shaped by a new metal that had not yet fully entered the world.

The Nart sagas remember the threshold before disruption — a mythic world poised at the edge of transformation, before the arrival of the stone that would become a child and before the forge would give birth to steel.
stages.falling-star:
The story begins with Satanaya, a beautiful matron who is not yet a mother.

Without the sun she gives warmth, without the moon she gives light, Lady Satanay.
Bright and hot, she beams from the top of her tower.
Click Clack go her heels, as she walks the Kuban banks.

An old shepherd sees her and calls to her, but he cannot cross the river. A love arrow is loosed. She moves. The arrow misses her and strikes a rock.

The star has fallen — but in mythic form.
The love arrow that misses its mark becomes the heavenly spark that awakens the stone.
stages.impact-crater:
A face appears in the stone.

Satanaya carries the stone to the smith, who keeps her secret of conception. She places the stone in her apron, in her fire, wrapped with wax, beneath her bed. There are many variants of the story, but the image remains constant: the stone becomes hot, swollen and ready.

Nine months later, in some tellings, she returns to the smithy.

The stone has gestated.
The heavenly object has crossed into the human world.
The meteor has entered the furnace.
stages.forge:
When the smith strikes the stone, the child is born.

The stone is struck.
The child is born.

Sosruquo enters the world through the blow of the hammer. His birth is inseparable from the forge.
stages.quenching:
The smith grips the baby by his thigh with his tongs and quenches him in liquid. The boy sizzles and steams. The smith repeats the process — hotter fires and more quenching.

When the process is finished, the boy declares his blood is steel.

In the sagas, he is impervious everywhere except his thigh — the place where he was held by the tongs.

In the story of Sosruquo, when he becomes impervious through quenching, maidens are present. Their inability to nurse him, and the way he burns through their aprons, reflects a progression. Quenching is aligned with nursing, yet distinguished from it as a new process. Nursing becomes a mirror that cannot reflect the new image on its own.

His quenching in milk becomes cosmic in scale.

The milk in which he is quenched comes from ninety-nine she-wolves. They are herded by the top dog, Sirius. These herded wolves are stars with milk gathered across the horizon.

This quenching in cosmic milk becomes a quenching in the heavens. As in the story of Romulus and Remus, Sosruquo also suckles a she-wolf. The milk represents cosmic nurture — discharge, restoration, and empowerment in the embrace of the cosmos.
stages.integration:
Sosruquo demands the embers poured down his throat.

The image preserves a metallurgical truth: when heated with charcoal, carbon moves into the blade. For iron to reach full strength, it demands carbon.

What had once been impurity becomes the power within him.
stages.drawing:
Sosruquo is raised by his mother at the fringe of society.

The meteor hero emerges from the margins — from the edges of the known world — carrying a strength that disrupts the center.
stages.new-age:
The story of Sosruquo preserves a complete mythic memory of the steel-forging sequence:

Stone.
Forge.
Hammer.
Quench.
Weakness.
Integration.
Hero.

He is born from stone, forged by a smith, quenched into invulnerability, strengthened by embers, and marked by a single vulnerable place.

Sosruquo stands as a mythic embodiment of meteor steel — a hero whose body preserves the memory of the forge and the birth of a new age.

stages.golden-age:
Greek myth remembers the progression of ages as a series of disruptions: the Age of Gold, the Age of Silver, the Age of Bronze, the Age of Heroes, and the Age of Iron. This was not imagined. This is the order in which these metals became useful. Each was a real technological age that held space in history and added its layers to mythic memory.

When we focus on the technological progression from Bronze to Iron, Meteor Steel appears in the seam — like the Age of Heroes, the time of Achilles and the revolution of Prometheus.

In Greek myth, when Prometheus stole fire from the heavens, it triggered the onset of the Iron Age. The fire he stole, according to Plato, was the skill of Hephaestus’ flame.

The flame that first sparked the Iron Age was an iron meteorite.

The Trojan War was set in 1200 BC — when the Bronze Age was collapsing and the Iron Age was on the rise. Achilles, the most powerful warrior in the Trojan War, gave myth to the transition.
stages.falling-star:
When Prometheus stole fire from the heavens, he stole the craft of Hephaestus.

The heavenly fire of the forge becomes the heavenly origin of iron and steel.
The skill of Hephaestus’ flame becomes the spark of a new age.

Between Prometheus and Hephaestus, the myth preserves the memory of heavenly fire descending to earth — the arrival of a disruptive power that would reshape human history.
stages.impact-crater:
The armor of Achilles was made by Hephaestus — Vulcan — who was grasped by the foot and thrown from the heavens. This fall became his weakness.

Between Achilles and his armorer, we find the image of the fallen star, impervious armor, and a shared weakness in the foot.

Another mirror appears.

When Athena dodges Hephaestus’ seed, Erichthonius — founder of Athens — is born from the Earth.

This mirrors the arrival of meteor steel:
a heavenly spark misses its intended target and enters the ground, giving birth to a hero of the city.

Hephaestus falls from heaven.
His seed falls to earth.
A child of earth is born.

The meteor has entered the ground.
stages.forge:
The armor of Achilles was forged by Hephaestus.

In ancient civilizations, metallurgists and smiths were nearly indivisible from priestly orders. In myths of ancient clans, we find mentor-smiths and smith-chieftains.

Hephaestus stands as the divine image of the smith whose work bridges heaven and war.

When warriors fell to injury or the loss of an eye, they commonly contributed to shops and smithies. Their contributions could be decisive. This memory survives in the thunderbolts and superior weapons made by Hephaestus and his team.

The forge becomes the place where the wounded transform power into technology.
stages.quenching:
Earlier metals were not quenched. They were heated and allowed to cool.

When hot steel is quenched in cool liquid, the rapid cooling creates a hard skin that holds an edge. Before quenching, steel was a stronger metal than had been previously mastered. Quenched, it became harder.

Steel is not harder where it is held when quenched. This spot tempers unevenly and remains soft — softer than bronze. This is the Achilles Heel.

Like steel, Achilles was impervious to the weapons of his day.
Like steel, he had a soft spot.
Like steel, this soft spot is where he was held when quenched — in the Styx by his mother.
stages.integration:
The greatest hero in the Trojan War did not exemplify religious purity.

Achilles did not stand for god, king or country, nor for moral purity or the purity of his soul. He stood for the friend he lamented, for the woman he defended, for his own rights, and for mortal excellence as immortal glory.

As the wholeness of steel includes carbon, his wholeness included the drives of our mortal bodies.

His most heroic act came from human hurt, revenge and anger.
His most sacrilegious deed bound the image of his wound to the image of his darkness.

The sacrilegious tether around Hector’s ankles was sewn through his tendons — through his Achilles’ heels — joining the image of his wound with the image of his shadow.
stages.drawing:
Heavenly armor was all but immortal.
Swords of fallen light could cut through bronze.

To exclude the disruptive presence of steel in the Trojan War would have been like forgetting the nuclear explosions of WWII.

The forge, the armor, and the hero step onto the battlefield together.
stages.new-age:
Iron Age values and motifs — from Achilles’ Heel to the Sword in the Stone — appear again and again in hero after hero.

Meteor steel sparked the Age of Heroes and reshaped the heroic imagination.

Between Prometheus, Hephaestus and Achilles we find the full pattern:

Fallen fire.
Fallen smith.
Heavenly seed in earth.
Forged armor.
Quenched invulnerability.
Single weakness.
Hero reshaping the age.

The Age of Heroes remembers the arrival of meteor steel in mythic form.

stages.golden-age:
Before the metallurgical breakthrough of quenching, heroic invulnerability belonged to older paradigms of fire, purity, lineage, and divine birth.

Jason and Hercules both emerge from this world as divine children with dual parentage, standing at the threshold between precious-age mythology and the disruptive Age of Heroes.

The Age of Heroes was remembered as a hinge between Bronze and Iron, and these heroes stand precisely at that hinge — born into a world still shaped by older metallurgical metaphors, yet already leaning toward a new technological and mythic reality.

Hercules and Jason inherit divine lineage, embodying the transitional figure who carries heavenly inheritance into earthly conflict. Their birth situates them within the tradition of heroes who stand between heaven and earth — a pattern that will later become central to meteor-steel heroes.

The precious-age world values purification and fire alone.
Yet the heroes who will undergo quenching have already been born.
stages.falling-star:
The calling that shapes the Argonauts is tied directly to metallurgy and Prometheus.

The mysteries experienced by the Argonauts were those of the Kabeiroi, whose rites were deeply related to metallurgy and who held Prometheus as their first patron.

Prometheus — the bringer of divine fire — stands behind the metallurgical calling that draws these heroes into initiation.

Hercules is deeply connected to arrows, projectiles, and divine weapons, extending the imagery of fire and heavenly force descending into the world. These projectile images mirror the falling meteor and the arrival of disruptive power from above.

The Argonaut expedition becomes a response to this metallurgical calling:
a journey shaped by divine fire and the promise of technological transformation.

The calling is not merely adventure.
It is initiation into the mysteries of fire and metal.
stages.impact-crater:
The Argonauts cross into the unknown through water — the mythic mirror of the quenching bath.

On his quest with Jason, Hercules is swallowed by whale and sea.
When he returns, his hair has been burned away.

The imagery fuses:

• Submersion
• Burning
• Transformation
• Return

This moment functions as the threshold crossing of metallurgical initiation.

While under water, like quenching steel, the Argonauts were initiated.

The journey becomes descent into an initiatory underworld.

This is the crossing into the metallurgical mysteries.
stages.forge:
The Argonauts undergo esoteric initiation.

Their rites:

• Were deeply related to metallurgy
• Were run by a secret order
• Were never described openly

This absence is intentional.

Esoteric traditions conceal the inner experience and present an exoteric myth as its visible mirror.

The initiates wore rings of power — magnetized iron — forged by initiates.

When they clasped hands in dexiosis,
their iron secret was invisibly shared.

Iron becomes a carrier of hidden knowledge.

Technology becomes initiation.
Brotherhood becomes metallurgy.
stages.quenching:
Here the metallurgical symbolism becomes explicit.

Jason bathes in a river at Medea's instruction to become invulnerable.

Later, Medea renews the body of his father by dunking him in a cauldron.

Liquid immersion becomes:

• Invulnerability
• Renewal
• Rebirth

Hercules also carries the quenching motif.

He wore impervious skin — yet the skin he received from crossing a river became his mortal weakness.

The pattern is unmistakable:

Heat + Water → Hardened Skin + Weak Spot

The metallurgical process has entered myth.
stages.integration:
The Argonaut story contains a structural split:

• Inner initiation remains hidden
• Outer myth reveals its symbolic echo

Hercules becomes the visible mirror of the hidden rites.

Swallowed by the sea before the initiation,
he returns from the waters when the rites are complete.

In Greek myth and mystery cults,
his submersion and burned hair are understood as the exoteric echo of metallurgical initiation.

The myth reflects the rite.
The hero reflects the initiate.
stages.drawing:
In a mysterious visual tradition, Jason is born from the mouth of a monster beneath the Golden Fleece.

The hero emerges from the belly of a beast.

This is rebirth imagery tied to metallurgical transformation.

The hero who has undergone immersion emerges renewed, hardened, and transformed.

The myth now mirrors the completed metallurgical sequence.
stages.new-age:
Jason, Hercules, and the Argonauts stand at the technological hinge of history.

To move from gold and bronze to iron and steel required:

• Hotter fires
• Rapid cooling
• The discovery of quenching

Their myths preserve the emotional and symbolic impact of this shift.

Across their stories we find:

• River immersion
• Cauldron renewal
• Secret metallurgical initiation
• Rings of iron power
• Burning and submersion
• Impervious skin with a weakness

The Argonauts become mythic carriers of the metallurgical revolution.

Their voyage becomes a vessel for the arrival of quenching, iron, and steel into the heroic imagination.

They stand as initiates of the Age of Heroes —
the moment when fire alone was no longer enough,
and the world learned to temper steel.

stages.golden-age: Interestingly, Ayyanar is also a deity that supports an abandonment of the caste system. His figure did not support the system of purification. We find this iron-related deity on the side of those who would overthrow tyranny, like Prometheus and the Iron Age Indo-Europeans. From Sosruquo to the Hindu Ayyanar to Jesus, we find special children on earth where a heavenly light has pointed, or where an arrow has landed.
stages.falling-star: The Dravidian child of steel, Ayyanar, whose name means "precious stone," was also found at the landing place of an arrow from the heavens, born of stone and associated with a single weakness. He is a Dravidian deity who arrives on earth as an arrow from heaven and is born from a stone found where that arrow landed. Ayyanar is also known as Sasta, a name also used for Buddha. Like Sosruquo, he is blue or blackish. In the Lakota-Sioux figure of Fallen Star, we find another association of a divine child with a fallen star. In this case, his immortality is lost when the star is removed, repeating the association of starlight with the immortal aspect of self and its differentiation from the mortal body. As seen in the ascetic figure of Ayyanar, the ascetic is dedicated to purifying a relationship with an immortal seed by reducing the dimming effects of mortal materiality.
stages.impact-crater: Ayyanar is born from stone. His stone is associated with a meteor, and he is consistently described as born from stone. The crater motif also appears in the association of the love arrow and first plowing. From stone, Ayyanar emerges from the meteor stone while the Buddha emerges from mother and elephant.
stages.forge: The association of the meteor with asceticism begins to clarify in the figure of Ayyanar, whose name means "precious stone." The path from meteor stone to asceticism is direct when we see the association of Ayyanar with the Yogapatta. He is clearly a man of steel from a meteorite, he is weak at the knees like Sosruquo, and his single weakness is directly connected with an ascetic weakness. When we continue to look deeper into the metaphors associated with iron that relate to ascetic philosophies, we begin to ask ourselves what we associate with the corrupting. From Greek to Hebrew mythology we find an association of matter with mother and pattern with father. The ascetic spiritualities that pursue purification of spirit from the corruption of body are pursuing purification of spirit from matter. In the meteor we find the stone to be the vessel of the elixir, and we find iron to be strongest and least corruptible when mixed with mater.
stages.quenching: One of the key features of a pilgrimage to worship Ayyanar is the plunging of the pilgrim in a river. This is associated with a ritual in which an ascetic is given their Yogapatta following this quenching. Ayyanar statues are dunked in water, and this is also done with the Buddha. The golden bowl appears in this quenching tradition.
stages.integration: The Yogapatta is a strap that wraps around the knees and waist to take pressure off the knees and to make the meditating body firm to support ascetic efforts. This device is designed to protect the meditator from the major physical weakness that emerges when one attempts to meditate: the knees. This single weakness to which we attend after ceremonial quenching is the key physical weakness of the ascetic.
stages.new-age: Buddhism is associated with the Iron Age.

stages.golden-age: In the sprawling tapestry of Chinese mythology, few figures shine as brightly as Sun Wukong, the Monkey King. His narrative, as recorded in the classic novel Journey to the West, provides a compelling Chinese example of how the meteor-steel motif appears within the global heroic tradition. Sun Wukong is inseparable from his weapon, the Ruyi Jingu Bang—an iron staff whose uncanny ability to change size and weight symbolizes not only the Monkey King's strength but also his adaptability and fluid nature. It acts as an extension of his character, much as meteor steel can be seen as a divine extension of the hero in various global myths. Like many steel heroes, Sun Wukong emerges in opposition to heavenly hierarchy. His role as an antiheroic challenger of hierarchical purity resonates with the rebellious character of iron against gold. His defiance of the celestial court and his initial selfish motives align him with an unconventional heroic model: neither purely noble nor wholly ignoble, but complex and disruptive. In the mythology of Heaven, this rebellion unfolds under the rule of the Jade Emperor.
stages.falling-star: His origin carries the signature of heavenly descent. The celestial connection of Sun Wukong's birth mirrors the otherworldly origins associated with meteor steel. His ability to leap vast distances and fly on clouds further connects him to this celestial imagery, embodying motion between heaven and earth.
stages.impact-crater: That heavenly connection becomes literal in his birth. Sun Wukong is born from a stone that absorbed the essence of Heaven and Earth, fusing the celestial and the terrestrial. This origin echoes the symbolic pattern of heavenly material embedded in the earth. In motif form, the Monkey King appears alongside themes of the golden tyrant, the iron weapon, and birth from stone.
stages.forge: Like many heroes in this tradition, Sun Wukong undergoes a trial by fire. In Journey to the West, after his rebellion in Heaven, the gods attempt to execute him but fail. Laozi then proposes placing him inside the Eight Trigrams Furnace so that his body can be broken down and refined by sacred fire. Sun Wukong remains inside the furnace for forty-nine days while the flames are stoked to reduce him to ash. Instead of destroying him, the fire strengthens him. When the furnace is opened, he emerges alive, his body unharmed and his eyes transformed into what later traditions call "fiery golden eyes." After leaving the furnace, he is stronger than before and resumes his defiance of Heaven.
stages.quenching: The Monkey King's weapon also carries a strong association with water. His iron staff is said to have originated from the depths of the Eastern Sea Dragon Palace, linking the weapon directly to the ocean.
stages.integration: His powers continue to expand in unusual ways, including the ability to pluck out a hair and become invisible.
stages.drawing: The iron staff itself remains central: the Monkey King is repeatedly identified with the iron bar weapon he wields.
stages.new-age: Taken together, Sun Wukong provides a vivid illustration of the meteor-steel hero within the Chinese cultural context. His story reflects themes of transformation, rebellion, strength, and the connection between heaven and earth. As part of the global heroic tradition, the Monkey King stands alongside other figures who carry the recurring motifs of meteor steel.

stages.falling-star: When we see a light from the heavens come down as a stone from which an unstoppable sword is extracted… the sword from the stone is a meteor sword. The Holy Grail and the sword from the stone share a common origin in this imagery of heavenly stone descending to earth. The Grail is remembered as a sacred stone from the heavens, and the sword drawn from the stone reflects the same celestial source. If the Grail and Excalibur are both understood as meteoric stone, they share a common heavenly origin. The stone from which Excalibur comes is a meteor. Its wielder is a man of steel… The one with the meteor sword is the one with the heavenly light and the divine right to rule.
stages.impact-crater: So when we look at the sword of Arthur and its meteor roots, we recognize a memory of the real struggle to extract a big meteor from the earth to make swords with. We also recognize the rare ability to transform that stone into a sword. Only the smith was able to do this — to extract swords from stone. Arthur draws the sword from the stone.
stages.forge: Arthur's forging and road of trials appears in his development under the tutelage of Merlin.
stages.quenching: But what of the Lady of the Lake? There are two origin stories of Excalibur — the stone and lake. This is because the first iron swords were first drawn from stone and then drawn from water, as quenching was essential to their hardening process… the iron sword coming in and out of water is a mythic transmutation of a literal process in which the sword was quenched. And this tells us why Arthur is undefeatable with this sword… Arthur's invincibility is an echo of Batraz as a personification of steel, which was invulnerable to lesser metals… it is the hardened exterior of iron after it has been quenched in water. When Arthur lay dying at the battle of Badon, after he and his son Mordred cut each other down, his attendant Bedevere came to his side. Arthur told Bedevere to throw his miraculous sword into a body of water… He denied Arthur three times… Only then did he finally return the sword to those waters from which it came.
stages.integration: Arthur assembles the Knights of the Round Table.
stages.drawing: Arthur draws the sword from the stone and becomes king.

stages.golden-age: Sigurd and Siegfried stand within a world defined by gold, cursed wealth, and tyrannical family control. The gold ring represents gold, curse, power, and wealth, and it remains a memory of the struggle with the golden ethic. The golden tapestry itself becomes the setting of downfall, and the warrior Attila defeats the wealthy Burgundians and Rome, suggesting that Rome also fell because of its love of the dragon gold and ring. By then, Roman elites did not fight their own wars, just as the Burgundians had Siegfried fight for them. This is a world of toxic and tyrannical family control under the rule of the golden tyrant.
stages.falling-star: Sigurd is associated with invisibility and unusual parentage. In the tale of Siegfried, he embodies the divine essence but is perceived in the earthly guise of Gunnar.
stages.impact-crater: The crater motif appears repeatedly in the story. The sword splits the anvil in half, showing the cleaving and cratering power now turned against the anvil itself. The crater structure appears again when Sigurd kills the dragon from a ditch, and the critical moment in which he stabs the dragon takes place while he stands within this ditch, evoking the crater.
stages.forge: Siegfried is steeped in steel motifs. Siegfried is raised in seclusion by Mime, a dwarf associated with metallurgy and the forge. Sigurd is raised by Reginn, an iron worker and the brother of the dragon from which the dragon blood comes. The sword Gram is a broken sword like Aragorn's and the one the royal family keeps, but it is also an expression of forge welding. This forge welding represents a greater skill than making the original sword. Like Sosruquo and many others, it is his father's sword.
stages.quenching: Sigurd is quenched in dragon's blood. Blood quenching appears across the stories, and Sigurd's dragon blood is directly associated with this motif. Sigurd stands among the figures who are quenched, bathed, or baptized, including Jesus, Sosruquo, Sigurd, Cu Chulainn, and Wolverine.
stages.integration: After exposure to the dragon's blood, Sigurd gains the ability to hear animals, recalling the shamanic motif and the white snake story that inverts the idea that animals stopped speaking with humans after the snake. He also possesses a special horse, like the Narts, showing the closeness between the hero and the horse.
stages.drawing: Sigurd and Thor are described as impervious, and the hammer is impervious. The leaf weak spot appears in the older story of Sigurd, where a leaf covers the place untouched by dragon blood. The same can be said about the single weakness of Siegfried and the dragon blood of invincibility. The hero's weak spot becomes the weak spot of steel, seen in later poeticized stories of Achilles and Sigurd. Sigurd joins Sosruquo, Achilles, and Jason among the heroes marked by a single weakness.
stages.new-age: The story culminates in Ragnarok, where the golden age is brought down and a new world emerges. The prominence of Siegfried helped bring Norse mythological figures to the forefront of German cultural consciousness, and Tolkien later echoed elements of the Volsunga Saga and the Nibelungenlied, with Aragorn paralleling the Germanic hero Siegfried and the Norse hero Sigurd.

stages.golden-age: In the Second Battle of Mag Tuired, Ireland is ruled by the Fomorians, oppressive beings who demand tribute, tax the harvest, and kill Lugh's father Cian. Lugh arrives at the court of Tara and demands entry, repeatedly refused unless he possesses a unique skill. He lists many skills—smith, warrior, harpist, poet—and is finally admitted as Samildánach, the master of all arts. He ultimately leads the Tuatha Dé Danann in overthrowing the tyrant Balor and the oppressive regime.
stages.falling-star: Lugh is strongly associated with light, brightness, and the sun, and his festival Lughnasadh celebrates the late summer sun and harvest. While there is no myth of falling star or heavenly descent, he stands as a divine light figure whose presence represents a new light entering the world.
stages.impact-crater: Lugh kills the tyrant Balor using a projectile stone. In the myth, he slings a stone through Balor's destructive eye, defeating the oppressive king. The stone projectile becomes the defining image of the moment the tyrant falls.
stages.forge: Lugh's identity as Samildánach, master of all arts, includes the skills of the smith and warrior. He represents the union of craft, skill, and martial power. Lug turns red hot with anger as a natural physiological response. This is when he announces at a feast the murderers of his father Cian.
stages.integration: Lugh's mastery of many arts represents the refinement of skill and the perfection of craft.
stages.drawing: Lugh's defining weapon is the projectile stone, used to kill Balor. The sling stone becomes the decisive weapon that brings down the tyrant.
stages.new-age: The defeat of Balor and the Fomorians marks the overthrow of an oppressive order and the beginning of a new world under the Tuatha Dé Danann.

stages.golden-age: Cú Chulainn is a hero who repeatedly operates outside social order and hierarchy. As a child warrior, he protects Ulster single-handedly while the adult warriors are incapacitated, placing him outside the normal structures of power and authority.
stages.falling-star: Cú Chulainn is the son of Lugh, a god associated with light and brightness, placing him within a divine heroic lineage.
stages.forge: There's some evidence for Celtic. Cú Chulainn is called the frenzied one in one of his tales and is in a heated frenzy in another.
stages.quenching: When he returns from his exploits, Cú Chulainn has to be dunked to cool off. Celtic Cú Chulainn, when he comes back from his rage, is dunked in three vats of water, and is rendered, first stunned by the vision of 50 naked women. And then they grab him and dunk him in the water. Steel has to be tempered. It has to be rendered hard through various degrees of heating and immersion to strengthen it. This makes it dark. There are scales of darkness that will tell you how things have been quenched. There was always going to be a spot that is not quenched, because you have got to hold it somehow. This darkness is seen in the figures of Cu Chulain and Sosruquo, who goes through a process of heating and cooling in the smithy.
stages.integration: The process of heating and cooling appears again in the description of steel being tempered and darkened.
stages.drawing: Cú Chulainn wields the Gáe Bolga, a barbed spear that becomes unstoppable once released.
stages.new-age: Cú Chulainn stands as the great warrior of the Ulster Cycle.

stages.golden-age: Iron Hans begins in a golden royal setting in which the prince's golden sword symbolizes obedience.
stages.falling-star: The story includes a meteor motif associated with Iron Hans.
stages.impact-crater: Iron Hans is associated with a crater motif through the pond where he is found, and he is also associated with being from stone.
stages.forge: Iron Hans is the wild, iron-linked man who dwells in the woods and represents the untamed nature of masculinity. His narrative follows the evolution of a boy into a man under Iron Hans's guidance, emphasizing rites of passage, mentorship, and the realization of inherent strength. The motif of iron underscores the raw, unyielding force of the wild man archetype and embodies the trials and challenges that young men must confront and integrate to achieve mature masculinity. His story stands within the broader exploration of steel and iron motifs in narratives of maturing masculinity.
stages.quenching: Iron Hans is connected to quenching through being found in the pond and through the golden ring or key found in the well.
stages.integration: The narrative represents the journey from youth to maturity and highlights how metal symbolism reflects masculine growth, challenge, and sacrifice across cultures.
stages.drawing: The story includes a weak spot motif, and Iron Hans is associated with imperviousness through steel skin and the impervious trainee. The story also includes an invisibility cloak.
stages.new-age: At the end of the story, the boy completes the journey from youth to maturity under Iron Hans's guidance. The narrative culminates in the realization of inherent strength and the integration of the trials and challenges that must be confronted to achieve mature masculinity. The journey that began with the wild, iron-linked man in the woods resolves in a transformed identity and a new reality shaped by the completed passage into adulthood.

stages.golden-age: The challenge of Gilgamesh by the strength of Enkidu, described as heavenly stone, may represent a mythically imagined challenge by this metal long before it could even be used. Enkidu emerges as a counterbalance to the tyranny of Gilgamesh at the height of early civilization — a force from the wild periphery responding to imperial power. With Enkidu, it is the time before meteor steel was useful, yet a time when it was already recognized as strong and powerful.
stages.falling-star: Enkidu is described over and over as "mighty as a rock from the sky" after he is made of clay that is pinched off and "thrown down" to the steppes. "My father, there was a man came by the water-hole. Mightiest in the land, strength he possesses, his strength is as mighty as a rock from the sky." The association of clay thrown down from above with celestial origins reflects a deep human connection to the cosmos.
stages.impact-crater: "The goddess Aruru… took a pinch of clay, threw it down in the wild. In the wild she created Enkidu, the hero, offspring of silence, knit strong by Ninurta." Creation from clay directly ties Enkidu to the earth while simultaneously linking him to the heavens. In Sumerian mythology, humans are sometimes said to be created from clay and divine essence, and the association with lapis lazuli introduces the dual nature of being earthly and touched by the divine. Lapis lazuli, with its deep blue color and golden flecks, evokes the night sky and reinforces the celestial symbolism of stones. Enkidu, created during an "age of clay," represents an era where the connection between the terrestrial and celestial was symbolized by stones like lapis lazuli.
stages.forge: "In the wild she created Enkidu, the hero, offspring of silence." "All his body is matted with hair… he bears long tresses like those of a woman." "Coated in hair like the god of the animals, with the gazelles he grazes on grasses, joining the throng with the game at the water-hole." The wandering of Enkidu becomes "the wandering of the planets — why do you wander Enkidu, why are you erratic with the current paradigm." "Remove their hair — like Enkidu." The wild man archetype appears as a figure before civilization.
stages.quenching: "For six days and seven nights Enkidu was erect, as he coupled with Shamhat." This encounter becomes a symbolic moment of transformation, the sex with a woman appearing as the symbolic quenching of a sword and the reduction of battle frenzy in later stories. Later in the epic, Gilgamesh descends beneath the water to retrieve the flower of immortality, and the act of retrieving immortality itself becomes a descent under the water.
stages.integration: After the great journey, Gilgamesh enters a phase of reflection and return, dreaming, remembering, and ultimately recording the story in stone. The return becomes the reflective phase of the journey, culminating in the writing of the story itself in stone.
stages.drawing: The delivery of the stone as a story becomes the act that represents immortality, as Gilgamesh's story written in stone becomes his lasting immortality.
stages.new-age: "You are handsome, Enkidu, you are just like a god! Why with the beasts do you wander the wild?" Enkidu's narrative arc—from a wild man living with animals to a civilized human after his encounter with Shamhat and his friendship with Gilgamesh—reflects a journey of self-discovery and transformation. This represents the emergence of a new age shaped by story, memory, and civilization.

stages.golden-age: Hittite metallurgy was advanced, and, despite limited use, evidence points towards their ability to work iron. If the archaeologists have hit a vein, we should see iron in their myths. And if there is a relationship between the concurrent rise of iron and Indo-European civilizations, we might expect unique resonance between Hittite and Indo-European iron motifs. Upon investigation, we came across the birth of Ullikummi. Kumarbi, father of the gods… against the Storm-God a rebel he raises… The chieftain deity was a storm god, and when it is prophesied that this child will overthrow the storm god, this becomes a prophecy about the fall of what was at the time active leadership — a fall that would go on to occur with the rise of iron.
stages.falling-star: Meteors have historically been described as stones, and stories about heroes or warriors created from stone encode details that point toward meteor steel, like Ullikummi, the son of Kumarbi.
stages.impact-crater: Kumarbi's Son – Born from Stone. Into (thy) hand a staff take… now go… into the waters… when the middle night watch came… the stone… and they brought him to birth… the Rock away… Kumarbi's son… They brought him to birth, and the fate-goddesses and mother goddesses lifted the child… on Kumarbi's knees they placed him. The father of Ullikummi flows his manhood into the mother and rock that would bear his child. We mostly know him as a character made from stone, and the image of both a warrior and a blade drawn from stone emerges from this birth. Out of the body like a blade he sprang.
stages.forge: Ullikummi is not forged by smiths, but he is struck, attacked, and worked like an indestructible material. Created as a living weapon raised to overthrow the Storm God, he grows toward heaven and becomes the target of repeated attacks by the gods. The Storm God gathers the divine host and goes to war against him, striking him with storms and weapons, yet these blows fail. Ullikummi remains invulnerable while attached to the stone foundation from which he grows. Only when the gods retrieve the ancient cutting tool used to separate heaven and earth — a primordial blade belonging to the oldest gods — can he be cut loose from that foundation. Once severed from the stone base, he becomes vulnerable and can be defeated.
stages.quenching: The child is repeatedly described as being brought to birth "in the waters," and the final image presents the sword in water. Ullikummi is repeatedly described as a blade brought to birth in the waters, and parallels to the birth of Sosruquo are striking.
stages.drawing: He is repeatedly described as both a warrior and a blade drawn from stone. What is the child that truly overthrew the world order? Steel. This is the story about the iron apocalypse before the iron apocalypse came. The Hymn to Ullikummi is dated to the century prior to the Hittite and Bronze Age collapse. This is a story born out of the early discovery of iron and the accurate prediction that it would bring about an apocalypse.
stages.new-age: When we look at the mythology of the Hittites, who seem to have had steel technology before their peers, we find a story of a "blade" made of "stone" who is destined to challenge the divine hierarchy and bring about an apocalypse. In the story, which was written some centuries before the Bronze Age collapse, this world ending threat is thwarted, but eventually, the Hittites fell, Iron technology proliferated, and, in concert with a number of other factors, the Bronze Age collapsed. The parallel to modern times is haunting. We all know that if Russia collapses, nuclear proliferation will be a nightmare, and it could bring about the end of the world. We write stories about this almost happening. It seems that the Hittites did as well, only the world ending weapon of the time was iron. This was before they and the Bronze Age collapsed.

stages.golden-age: In the Armenian epic, Mher cannot live in the normal human world because it has become corrupt and unjust. He stands as a heroic figure who no longer fits the moral condition of the world around him, and this alienation from the existing order marks the starting point of his story.
stages.falling-star: Mher is described with radiant, fiery imagery and rides a blazing horse, giving him strong solar and celestial associations even though he is not a literal falling-star hero.
stages.impact-crater: At the end of the epic, Mher rides to a rock mountain that opens to receive him. He rides inside, and the stone closes behind him. He becomes a hero sealed inside the mountain, waiting within the rock itself.
stages.forge: Mher is known for uncontrollable rage and destructive strength. His overwhelming battle fury mirrors the heated hero motif that requires cooling and restraint.
stages.quenching: The Armenian hero Mher has to be dunked in seven vats of water to cool him.
stages.integration: His withdrawal from the world represents a pause and suspension, a waiting period between ages.
stages.drawing: Mher is a mounted warrior hero equipped with sword, mace, and full war gear.
stages.new-age: Mher remains sealed in the mountain until the world becomes just again, waiting to return at the end of the age to restore order.
